home_preferences.ideal_family: Homes where kittens get plenty of love, play, and companionship.
home_preferences.ideal_environment: Mostly indoors, but they’ll enjoy safe outside adventures when possible.
outdoor_options: A catio or enclosed patio if you have one
A backyard with supervision (or recall training), or short leash/harness outings
GPS or smart collars (Tractive, Pawfit) — great for peace of mind when you are comfortable with them roaming
Or any other creative arrangement that feels right for both safety and joy
safety_notes: Use common sense to find the sweet spot between keeping them safe and keeping them happy.
gps_note: Fun fact: A real GPS tracker needs both satellite signals and a cellular data connection.

A GPS tracker 'listens' to satellites to know where it is. It usually needs signals from 3–4 satellites — a satellite only tells you how far away you are, not the direction. If you draw three circles on paper, the point where they overlap is your exact location.
The tracker also uses internal motion sensors (like a phone’s accelerometer) to estimate speed and direction.
But the tracker still needs a cell network to send that location to your phone. If either signal is weak — poor satellite line-of-sight or poor cellular coverage — the tracker won’t update.
GPS satellite signals themselves are free to use (maintained by the U.S. government), but the cellular networks are not.
Trackers send only tiny amounts of data, but companies like Tractive still need to pay Verizon, AT&T, or T-Mobile for that cellular access. That's why there's a small monthly fee.

This leads to a common confusion: people assume that because Bluetooth tags or AirTags can help find things, they should also work for tracking pets. Bluetooth only works at short range when a phone is physically nearby. It cannot track long distances or follow a moving animal.

Another common confusion is that 'GPS is free, so why am I paying monthly?' GPS only tells the tracker where it is — the subscription covers the cellular data needed to send that location to your phone in real time.

An AirTag is basically just a beacon. It doesn't know where it is at all. If your phone (or someone else’s iPhone) gets close enough, the iPhone does the smart work: estimating direction and distance, then placing it on the map.

A GPS tracker is a navigation device. It actually knows where it is, where it's going, and sends live updates directly to your phone. AirTags rely on nearby iPhones; GPS trackers rely on satellites and cell networks.
